August 14, 2013

Introduction

The VLIB bundle comprises the Texas Instruments Vision Library package together with the software tools (SWTOOLS) and all dependent packages in bundle format to simplify the release procedure.

Getting Started

The VLIB User's Manual provides the documentation and references necessary to integrate VLIB Library routines into a development platform.

Documentation

The following documentation is available:

User's Manual [HTML]
Test Report [HTML]
Software Manifest [HTML]
Release Notes Archive [LINK]

What's New

The following new features were added relative to VLIB 2.1:

  1. Aligned directory structure and package to use similar template as IMGLIB and DSPLIB
  2. Support for C66 and C674 compiled libraries
  3. VLIB_image_rescale
  4. Histogram Equalization
    • VLIB_histogram_equal_8
    • VLIB_histogram_equal_8_f32 (C66)
  5. VLIB_xyGradients (cutdown version of VLIB_gradientsAndMagnitudes)
  6. VLIB_xyGradients_Magnitude_Orientations
  7. VLIB_xyGradients_Magnitude_Orientations_F32 (C66)
  8. VLIB_HOG_cell_f32 (C66)
  9. Kalman Filter Floating point variants (C66)
    • 2x4_F32
    • 2x4_S16_F32
    • 4x6_F32
    • 4x6_S16_F32
  10. L2 Normalization
    • VLIB_L2_norm_i8
    • VLIB_L2_norm_i16
    • VLIB_L2_norm_i32
    • VLIB_L2_norm_f32 (C66)
  11. VLIB_bhattacharyaDistance_F32 (C66)
  12. VLIB_nonMaxSuppress_U32
  13. VLIB_harrisScore_U32_7x7
  14. VLIB_goodFeaturestoTrack
  15. VLIB_trackFeaturesLucasKanade_7x7_track_error
  16. VLIB_grayscale_morphology
  17. FAST9/FAST12
  18. ORB
  19. C66x Intrinsic optimized kernels for:
    • L2 Normalization
    • Histogram Equalization
    • Image Gradients Orientation and Binning
  20. Partial MISRAC 2004 Compliance (with deviations)

The following bugs have been resolved relative to VLIB 2.1:

  1. VLIB_trackFeaturesLucasKanade_7x7 fix
  2. VLIB_moment_2x2 fix
  3. VLIB_nonMaxSuppress_U32
  4. VLIB_initUYVYint_to_LABpl_LUT
  5. Resolved Doxygen inconsistencies and warnings
  6. Resolved all compiler warnings

Upgrade and Compatibility Information

This version of VLIB is compatible with the last released version:

YES
NO X

Note:
  1. Package compatibility keys are independent of component release versions. For more information visit: Package Versioning and Compatibility

Device Support

This release supports the following device families:

  • C66 DSP (ELF, Little-Endian format)

Validation Information

This release was built and validated using the following tools:

  • XDC Tools version: 3.25.00.48
  • RTSC Packaging Standard version: 2.0
  • C6000 Code Generation Tools version: 7.4.2
  • Code Composer Studio version: V5.4
  • GNU make version: 3.81

Known Issues

  1. Profiling benchmark representation needs to be normalized to input parameters
  2. Continue to reduce the MISRAC violations

Technical Support

Contact local TI Field Application Engineer for technical support.

Package Versioning and Compatibility

Compatibility Keys

Compatibility keys serve two primary purposes:

  1. Enable tooling to identify incompatibilities between components
  2. Convey a level of compatibility between different releases to set end user expectations.

Each compatibility key is composed of 4 comma-delimited numbers - represented here by the letters M, S, R and P [M,S,R,P]. The table below provides a descriptive reference for compatibility key intention.

Compatibility Key Reference
Key Meaning Description
1 (M=Major) Break in compatibility The package consumer is required to re-write the calling source code to use the package
2 (S=Source) Source compatibility The package consumer’s source code doesn't require change, but does require a recompile
3 (R=Radix) Introduction of new features Compatibility with previous interfaces is not broken. If libraries are provided by the package, an application must re-link with the new libraries, but is not required to recompile its source
4 (P=Patch) Bug fixes only If libraries are provided by the package, an application must re-link with the new libraries, but is not required to recompile its source.

Versioning

Each package version is composed of 4 period-delimited numbers - represented here by the letters M, m, p and b [M.m.p.b]. The table below provides a descriptive reference regarding package version numbering.

Package Version Reference
Digit Meaning Description
1 (M=Major) Major revision Incremented when the new version is substantially different from the previous For example, a new module added or an existing module's algorithm significantly altered.
2 (m=minor) Minor revision Incremented when the new version has changed but not in a major way. For example, some minor changes in the API or feature set.
3 (p=patch) Patch number Incremented for all other source code changes. This include any packaging support code.
4 (b=build) Build number Incremented for each release delivery to CM. Reset for any change to M, m or p
